head.title: School Closure Updates - Patterson Joint Unified School District

nav.div: Patterson Joint Unified School District » Staff » School Closure Updates

div.div: This page is inteded to keep our School Board and Staff updated on the latest important information regarding our school closure and COVID-19 related information.

span.style: font-size: medium; font-variant-ligatures: no-contextual; font-family: latobold; color: rgb(32, 33, 36);

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

span.style: font-variant-ligatures: no-contextual; font-size: medium; font-family: latobold; color: rgb(32, 33, 36);

div.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: small;

p.style: letter-spacing: normal; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-variant-ligatures: no-contextual; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif;

span.style: font-size: medium; font-family: latobold; color: rgb(32, 33, 36);

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

span.style: font-size: medium; font-family: latobold; color: rgb(32, 33, 36);

div.br:
Although it may not feel like it, Friday marks the beginning of our “traditional” Spring Break. We hope everyone is able to use this time to reconnect with family and friends – both those you’re sheltering with, and those you can only reach remotely. Please remind your students that daily classroom interactions will be on “pause” from April 10-19 and resume when we would normally return to school on April 20th. Unless there is an urgent message that needs to be communicated, we will not be sending updates during this time.
Chromebook Deployment
The last full day of Chromebook deployment will be tomorrow, Thursday April 9th, from 9 a.m.-3 p.m. at our District Office. A letter will be going out tomorrow informing all parents of a “last call” event scheduled for Tuesday, April 14th from 3 p.m.-7 p.m. to provide Chromebooks to those families who may have missed the opportunities this week – especially parents who are employed as essential workers and could not come by during our regular distribution hours. This letter will be posted on our website, distributed through PeachJar, and mailed to all families. It will also include information on support services for families caring for senior citizens and opportunities for free prescription services for those who may have lost their health insurance recently.
Grading Policies During the 2019-2020 School Closure
On Monday, April 6th our board passed a resolution to formally adopt guidelines provided earlier by the California Department of Education. This resolution amends Board Policy 5121 – Grading and Evaluation, to affirm that a student’s grade for the semester will not be lower than what they earned for their 3rd quarter (elementary) and P-5 progress report (secondary) prior to our school closures.
The CDE guidelines and flexibility provided by the University of California and California State University systems allow districts to adopt a “Pass/Fail” grading policy during the closure period. Our district does not believe that a simple “Pass/Fail” system would honor the work our teachers have been doing to continue providing learning opportunities for our students during this public health crisis. Additionally, it would deprive those students who are motivated and able to improve their grades during the 4th quarter the opportunity to do so. Essentially, a student who earns a “D” would receive the same “passing” mark as a student who earned an “A” at the end of the 3rd quarter under a simple pass/fail system.
Our District’s amended policy strikes a balance by providing students the opportunity to improve their grades, but not penalizing students who may not be able to fulfill all their academic obligations due to this public health crisis. Some of our older children may be providing child care while their parents go to work. Others may now be dealing with issues in the home that they normally can escape during the school day. With our campuses closed, this refuge is no longer available to them. These issues may be exacerbated by the stress and anxiety caused by our current circumstances.
Law enforcement is already reporting an increase in domestic violence calls since the "stay at home" orders have been implemented. We also can’t predict how many of our students will have confirmed cases of COVID-19 in their homes and be facing the serious health implications involved with such a diagnosis for themselves or a family member. We have seen how unpredictable this crisis can be and must adapt our policies to cover unforeseen circumstances for our students and staff.
Although our district has done an outstanding job deploying Chromebooks to all students, we also recognize that some families still do not have adequate access to wireless internet at home. However, can't continue to distribute and collect paper packets during this public health crisis. Theanticipated surge in new COVID-19 cases during the next 2-3 weeks would cause an unreasonable burden and unnecessarily jeopardize the health and safety of essential district employees still reporting to work.
We will continue to work with the 20% of our families who report that they do not have wireless internet access at home and will facilitate distance learning as best we can. We are currently using an interactive map provided by the State of California that pinpoints the exact level of service available for every address. This will allow us to accurately refer families to the correct service provider and effectively deploy our limited supply of hot spots where they are needed most.
Our Board and administration recognize that a few students may try to “game the system,” and this can be frustrating for our teachers and support staff. Please recognize that the vast majority of our students and parents appreciate everything you are doing to continue providing quality instruction under this unprecedented event! Under the current circumstances we need to be flexible with our grading and expectations and not worry about the few who may try to take advantage. It’s the right thing to do, and is consistent with what our State Board of Education has advised. Again, thanks to everyone's hard work, our District is in a better position than most to continue providing high quality distance learning.
Impact on the Class of 2020
The resolution approved by our Board on Monday also modifies the expectations for PREP this year. While fulfillment of PREP remains a graduation requirement, seniors will be provided multiple ways to present an abbreviated version. The biggest question on everyone’s mind – “What about the graduation commencement exercises for Patterson High and Del Puerto?” The simple answer is, we don’t know. Since the elimination of large public assemblies was among the first social distancing requirements put in place, it is logical to assume it will be the last to be removed.
The administration of Patterson High School will be hosting a WebEx meeting for all seniors and their parents on Thursday, April 9th at 5 p.m. to discuss ways to honor our graduating seniors during the school closure. We will also be soliciting their input on ways to honor our students now and what a future commencement ceremony might look like if public gathering orders aren’t lifted until the summer. We will also be covering the logistics for completing PREP, facilitating distribution of caps and gowns, yearbooks, refunds for senior events, effective processes for ongoing communication, and other issues unique to this class.
Enjoy the break. You've earned it! As always, stay safe, stay healthy, and stay strong!
IMPORTANT SCHOOL CLOSURE UPDATE #10 (4/7/20) As we prepare to enter what would traditionally have been our "Spring Break," a break is needed nonetheless. While our efforts have been focused on continuing to provide quality educational services for our students, it's also important that our staff take some time to relax. Our district office will be closed Friday and Monday. Services will resume, with a very limited staff, on Tuesday.

div.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: small;

span.div:
Tracy Manzoni and Ken Fitzgerald have put together some great resources to assist our staff during this crisis (see attached pdf). It is important that all of us take care of ourselves - both physically and mentally. Our efforts should now be focused on "bending the curve". As always, stay safe, stay healthy, and stay strong!
Staff Support Resources and Information.pdf

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

span.style: font-size: medium; font-variant-ligatures: no-contextual; font-family: latobold; color: rgb(32, 33, 36);

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: As everyone is aware, we are making a final push next week to get Chromebooks into the hands of all our students in grades TK-5. This will allow our students and their families to continue accessing the high quality instruction all our teachers are providing through distance learning. Our administrative team and IT department will be assisting those few families who still do not have access in their homes to help get them online as quickly as possible.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

strong.span: School Closure/Limited Access to School Campuses:

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: To assist with efforts to curb the spread of COVID-19, we will be closing access to all school campuses except for the purpose of distributing meals to students. Our campuses will be open Wednesday and Thursday April 8-9 from 9 a.m.-3 p.m., for those staff members who may need to retrieve personal belongings or educational resources to facilitate distance learning. You do not need to check out or turn in keys, and if you do not need to be on campus please honor the spirit of the current social distancing expectations and stay at home. However, we wanted to make this opportunity available to those who may need to do so.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: Access will also be given to students at Walnut Grove, Patterson High, and Creekside who may need to access their P.E. lockers or office to retrieve personal belongings. Students will not be given access to classrooms.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;
color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: Until last week, confirmed COVID-19 cases were only being reported county-wide. This policy changed, and as of this Saturday the number of confirmed cases in Patterson stands at five. Several staff members have asked if any of these cases pose a significant risk to students or employees of our district. We don’t believe so. Two district employees and a parent self-reported to us that a family member was being tested. Fortunately, all three of these tests came back negative. Additionally, our schools have now been closed for two weeks so any exposure risk resulting in a confirmed case would have occurred by now.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: If the Stanislaus County Health Services Agency alerts us of any potential risk to the health and safety of our students or staff, we will notify you immediately.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

strong.span: What Precautions Should I be Taking to Avoid Exposure Risk to COVID-19?

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: The three most important steps we can all take to avoid exposure and contamination continue to be practicing social distancing, disinfecting and sanitizing commonly shared surfaces, and thoroughly washing our hands. In the absence of a water source, hand sanitizer is a viable option.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: Many questions remain about the decay rates of the COVID-19 virus on various surfaces. Originally, it was found that the stability was less than 24 hours. New research suggests it can be as much as 72 hours on some surfaces.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: The use of “masks” and gloves to prevent the spread of COVID-19 and other infectious diseases is also unclear. Until recently, the Centers for Disease Control reported that masks were not useful, except if worn by those infected or health care professionals working with those infected. CDC has since modified this position and recommends the voluntary use of cloth masks in public spaces where social distancing may be difficult.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: The CDC does not recommend wearing gloves outside of a health care setting as an effective measure against the transmission of COVID-19. Latex gloves, when worn by health care professionals, are designed to prevent the spread of infectious diseases through bodily fluids when disposed of properly and efficiently. Gloves worn in a social setting will normally come in contact with multiple surfaces, in a non-sterile environment, and in a short period of time. This can actually increase risk of exposure for the wearer and others.

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;
p.strong: For updates on the latest research and recommendations to protect you and your family during this crisis, please visit:

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;
p.strong: For updates on confirmed cases in our region and ongoing efforts to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Stanislaus County, please visit:

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: For updates on code enforcement and compliance efforts to combat the spread of COVID-19 in Stanislaus County, please visit: Stanislaus County Sheriff Department

p.style: color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-size: 11pt; font-family: Calibri, sans-serif; letter-spacing: normal;

div.p: Thank you again for all you continue to do for our students and community. Stay safe, stay healthy, and stay strong!

span.style: letter-spacing: 0.3px; text-decoration: underline; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(0, 112, 192);

div.p: Patterson Unified School District does not discriminate on the basis of race, color, national origin, sex, age, or disability in admission to its programs, services, or activities, in access to them, in treatment of individuals, or in any aspect of their operations. The lack of English language skills shall not be a barrier to admission or participation in the district's activities and programs. Patterson Unified School District also does not discriminate in its hiring or employment practices.
